name: Green Alder tree
description: A member of the hardy Alnus viridis tree species, it is a thicket-forming Alaskan pioneer of the Betulaceae family with grey bark and greenish yellow leaves.  Adapted for growth in barren, nutrient-exhausted areas, it is one of the few trees suited for life within the arctic isles, though high wind speeds make it, by necessity, more akin to a fairly tall shrub than an actual tree.

name: arctic willow tree
description: This is a squat member of the Salix genus, ostensibly a form of willow tree adapted to grow in tundra and marine climates, though this specie’s brand of dwarfism lends it a greater kinship with deciduous shrubs.  Whip-like, reddish-purple stems branch from the plant’s core in an orb-like arrangement, with narrow, blueish-green leaves swaying in the breeze.
//: You should not be able to scale this, as Salix purpurea Nana grows to approximately 5 feet normally, even shorter on the Aleutians, which is quite a bit shorter than the established height for a single Z-level.

name: shaggy dune grass
description: A tangle of bluish green foliage with flowers and stout leaves — large rhizomes firmly embedding the vegetation into the sand from which it stretches.  This species of plant, prolific along the coasts, is the foundation of the indigenous Aleut people and their craft, used in thatching rooves, producing clothing, and for bedding.  The grass here is long enough that you could cut several healthy strands if you were of that inclination.

name: dune grass
description: A slick of stunted foliage — large rhizomes firmly embedding the vegetation into the sand from which it pokes greenish-blue tips.  This species of plant, prolific along the coasts, is the foundation of the indigenous Aleut people and their craft, used in thatching rooves, producing clothing, and for bedding.  However, the grass's usual thigh-high fronds are notable for their absence, and it’s doubtful that you’d be able to extract much usable material from what’s left.

name: rhododendron shrub
description: A native of the eastern Soviet Union, sub-arctic, and alpine regions, this deciduous bush sprawls across rocky terrain, unfurling dense folds of glossy green leaves and clusters of pink or white flowers.

//: Intended to be Athyrium filix femina.
name: lady fern
description: A feathery sprawl of green, lance-shaped fronds growing in a rosette from a central core, this elegant maiden of the natural ecology stands prim and upright as its foliage rustles in the wind.  Locals and colonists alike are known to steep the plant’s tresses in boiling water, forming teas to soothe labour pains.  For some reason, you suspect that you are more likely to find utility within its edible quadrants.
